msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Exodus 21
ab.l: And these are the judgmentswhich you shall set before them.
If youbuy a Hebrew servant, he shall serve six years and in the seventhhe shall go out free, for nothing.
If he, himself, comes in single,he, himself, shall go out in single. If he was a married man,then his wife shall go out with him as well.
If his master giveshim a wife, and she bears him sons or daughters, thewife and her children shall be her master’s, and he, himself, shall go outin single.
But if the servant plainly says,“I loved my master, my wife, and my children;I will not go out free:”

Then his master shall bring him to judges,and the judge shall bring him to the door orthe door post, and his master shall pierce his ear with an awl,and he shall serve him forever, that is, |until| the year of jubilee.And if a man sells his daughter as a servant,she shall not go out as the |men|servants go out.
Ifshe would seem bad in the eyes of her master who has designed her for himself,and he redeemed her, he shall have no right to sell her to another peoplein his deceiving of her.
And if he designates her for his own son,he shall deal with her according to the manner of daughters.
Ifhe takes another for himself, he shall not diminish her food, her clothing, andher place.
And if he does not do these threefor her, she shall go out for nothing, without silver.
One who strikes a man,and if he dies, he shall be surely put to death.
But if hedoes not hunt, but God makes the opportunity in his hand: I will seta place for you where he may flee.
But if a man plots againstanother to kill him by cunning, you shall take him from my altarto die.
And one who strikes his fatheror his mother shall be put to death.
And one who stealsa man and sells him, or if he is found in his hand,shall be surely put to death.
And one who curses his father orhis mother shall be surely put to death.
And if men quarrel,and one strikes another with a stone, or with his fist,and he does not die, but falls to his bed:
Ifhe rises, and walks outdoors leaning against his staff, the one who struck him shall be guiltless.Only he shall pay the compensation for his loss, and shall have himhealed.
And if a man strikes his servant or hismaidservant with a staff, and he dies under his hand, he shall be surelyavenged.
Just: if he stands for a day or two,he shall not be avenged, for he is his silver.

Andif men fight, and they hit a pregnant woman, andher children go out, and there would be no death, he shall be punishedaccording as the woman’s husband will lay on him. Butif they shall not be able to bargain, give this issue to the judges to judge.
But if there is death, then you shall givelife for life,
Eye for eye, tooth for tooth,hand for hand, foot for foot,
Burning wound for burning wound, open wound for open wound,bruise for bruise.
Andif a man strikes the eye of his servant or the eye of his maidservantand destroy it, he shall let him go free for his eye.
And if he causes his manservant’s tooth or his maidservant’s tooth to fall out,he shall let him go free for his tooth.
If a bull goresa man or a woman and they die,the bull shall be stoned with stones, and its flesh shall not be eaten,and the owner of the bull shall be guiltless.

And if thebull has been goring for long, and this is testifiedto its owner, and he does not watch it, and it kills a manor a woman, the bull shall be stoned with stones, andits owner shall be put to death as well.
If a ransomis laid on him, he shall give for the redemption of his life whateveris laid on him.
Whether it gores a sonor it gores a daughter, according to this judgment shall it be doneto it.
If the bull gores a |man|servant ora maidservant, he shall give to its master thirty mithqals of silver, and thebull shall be stoned with stones.
And if a man opensa well, or if a man digs a well and does not cover it, andan bull or a donkey fall in it,
The owner of the wellshall pay. He shall give back silver to its owner, and the dead oneshall be his.
And if a man’s bull hitsanother’s bull, and if it dies, they shall sell thelive bull, and divide in half the silverfor it, and they shall divide in half the dead one as well.
Or: if it is known that it is a goring bull for long,and its owner does not watch it,he shall pay a bull for the bull, and the dead one shall behis.
If a man steals a bull or a sheep and slaughters itor sells it, he shall pay him five oxenfor a bull, and four sheep for a sheep.

app.note: An interpretative addition to Exo 21:6, cf. TKow.01: ‘the meaning of which is “until the jubilee”’.
